metadata.chief_complaint: anxiety, detailed social history including bullying, divorce, custody, new stepparent, PHQ/GAD scores

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Hi Ava, hi Mom. I understand Ava's been dealing with some anxiety?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Yes. It's gotten worse over the past year. She worries about everything.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Ava, can you tell me what it feels like when you're anxious?

script.speaker: teen
script.text: My heart beats really fast and I feel like I can't breathe. Sometimes I feel like something bad is going to happen but I don't know what.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: That sounds really uncomfortable. How often does that happen?

script.speaker: teen
script.text: Almost every day. Especially before school.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: What do you think triggers it?

script.speaker: teen
script.text: I don't know. Just... everything. Tests, talking to people, what if I do something wrong.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: She's missed a lot of school because of it. Some days she just can't go.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: I want to understand what's going on in Ava's life. Can you tell me about home and school?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Well, her dad and I divorced two years ago. It was hard on both kids.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: What does the custody arrangement look like?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: We do week on, week off. She goes back and forth between houses.

script.speaker: teen
script.text: It's confusing. I never know where my stuff is.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: That does sound hard. Any conflict between your parents?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: We're civil but it was rough at first. And I remarried last year. My husband moved in with us.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: How is Ava adjusting to having a stepparent?

script.speaker: teen
script.text: He's okay. But it's weird. I don't really know him.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: She keeps to herself a lot when she's at our house.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: What about at school? Friends, social stuff?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: She had some trouble with girls at school earlier this year.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Trouble how?

script.speaker: teen
script.text: Some girls were being mean. Posting stuff about me on social media. Whispering when I walk by.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: That sounds like bullying. How long did that go on?

script.speaker: teen
script.text: A few months. It's kind of stopped now but I still don't trust anyone.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: We got the school involved but I don't know if it helped.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Ava, I'm going to ask you to fill out a couple of questionnaires about how you've been feeling. Is that okay?

script.speaker: teen
script.text: Sure.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Okay, I have her GAD-7 and PHQ-9 here.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Ava, your GAD-7 score is 14, which indicates moderate anxiety. Your PHQ-9 is 8, which is mild depression.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Depression too?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Anxiety and depression often go together. The good news is both are treatable.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: I need to ask some safety questions. Ava, have you ever thought about hurting yourself or not wanting to be alive?

script.speaker: teen
script.text: No. I'm scared of stuff, but I don't want to hurt myself.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Good. And have you ever hurt yourself on purpose, like cutting?

script.speaker: teen
script.text: No.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Okay, thank you for being honest. Here's what I recommend.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: First, therapy. I think cognitive behavioral therapy specifically would help a lot. It teaches you skills to manage anxious thoughts. I'm going to refer you to Dr. Singh.

script.speaker: teen
script.text: I've never done therapy before.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: That's okay. It's just talking to someone who can teach you new ways to cope. Most kids find it really helpful.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Does she need medication?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: I'd like to try therapy first. If she's still really struggling after six to eight weeks, we can add an SSRI. But let's give therapy a chance.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: That makes sense.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Also, I want to check in with you in three to four weeks to see how she's doing. And Ava, some basic things can help: regular sleep, limiting caffeine, exercise, time off screens.

script.speaker: teen
script.text: Okay.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: You've been through a lot of changes in the past two years. It makes sense that you're feeling anxious. But you don't have to feel this way forever.

script.speaker: teen
script.text: I hope so.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Thank you for taking this seriously.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Absolutely. I'll see you in a few weeks.
